subject: Philosophy
title: Bentham's Happiness Calculus
description: A quick, practical guide to Bentham's Happiness Calculus.

hook.text: Jeremy Bentham tried to turn morality into math. He wanted a formula for happiness.

buildup.text: His felicific calculus measured pleasure by intensity, duration, certainty, and nearness.

discovery.text: Add up all the pleasure, subtract all the pain, and the action with the highest score wins.

twist.text: It sounds elegant but fails in practice. How do you compare the joy of music to the relief of hunger?

climax.text: Bentham's calculus was never usable, but it forced people to take consequences seriously.

punchline.text: You can't calculate happiness. But you can count it.

quiz.question: What was Bentham's felicific calculus designed to measure?
options: The total pleasure and pain of an action
